abstracts.cdata!:
The project was satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and institutional development impacts
            substantial. While the performance by the Borrower is
            satisfactory, despite the uneven, overall implementation,
            until corrective measures were taken in late 1996-early
            1997, the Bank's performance is unsatisfactory, given
            the inappropriate implementation arrangements, and highly
            inadequate supervision in the early years, with changes in
            project objectives not adequately documented. Lessons
            highlight that critical public sector reforms are possible
            in a politically fragile environment, as proven by the
            success of the public finance reform, which was internalized
            because there was consensus for an improved budget
            management, otherwise government activities would have been
            suspended. However, idiosyncracy changes, could have
            fostered the well prepared, though sensitive civil service
            reform, which has yet to be implemented. Similarly,
            institutional development is uncertain, and requires a
            sustained engagement on the part of both the Government, and
            the Bank. Conversely, information technology can be
            successfully introduced in a poorly developed human resource
            environment, provided external assistance, close attention
            to technology transfer, and training programs are in place.
            Finally, minimizing the financing of recurrent costs, was
            paramount for project sustainability, while donor
            coordination would have served better, under one influential
            leadership role in a specific area of the national program.
